main event: In March 1955, a civilian reported observing a brilliant and orange-red object, the size of a nickel held at arm's length, traveling across the sky from east to west near Catalina Isle, California, for approximately 2 minutes.
interesting points: The sighting was classified as a ground-visual observation with photos taken by the civilian witness.
The object was described as very brilliant and orange-red in color, resembling the size of a nickel held at arm's length.
The report mentions the possibility of the object being astronomical, but the brevity of the sighting warranted further investigation.

Multiple potential conclusions were listed, including 'Was Balloon,' 'Probably Balloon,' 'Possibly Balloon,' 'Was Aircraft,' 'Probably Aircraft,' 'Possibly Aircraft,' 'Was Astronomical,' 'Probably Astronomical,' and 'Insufficient Data for Evaluation.'
The observation was deemed worthwhile by the investigating organization, despite the range of potential conclusions.
